title: 103_s2439
content: The Act is titled the "Fire Safety and Prevention Education Act". It includes findings related to fire safety. Congress finds that fire losses in the United States result in 5,000 deaths and 29,000 injuries annually, with an economic loss of $10 billion per year. Targeted fire safety education at the State and local levels has proven effective in preventing fires and reducing losses. However, fire departments' budgets for education have been significantly reduced or eliminated. There is a need to expand State and local fire safety education programs to support prevention efforts. Fire departments in other countries allocate 4 to 10 percent of their budgets to fire prevention, compared to less than 3 percent in the United States. Accurate data collection on fire incidents is crucial for targeting educational efforts effectively. The section defines key terms related to fire prevention and incident data collection. The Act defines key terms related to fire prevention and incident data collection, including the Administrator, eligible entity, fire safety and prevention education program, and State. Additionally, the Act applies to Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and other U.S. territories or possessions. SEC. 4. FIRE SAFETY AND PREVENTION EDUCATION. The Administrator may contract with eligible entities to distribute fire safety education programs and resources at the state and local level. Funds must be allocated as follows: 25% for statewide programs, 25% for new regional or local programs targeting high-risk populations, and at least 50% for awards of up to $10,000 each for existing regional or local programs. The Administrator may contract with eligible entities to distribute fire safety education programs and resources at the state and local level, allocating funds for statewide, regional, and local programs targeting high-risk populations. Effective prevention measures must be in place before receiving funds to prevent fires, fire deaths, injuries, and dollar losses. The Administrator can partner with States to enhance fire data collection through the National Fire Incident Reporting System. Eligible entities must apply for contracts, agreements, or grants as required. An eligible entity receiving funds under section 4 must submit an annual report to the Administrator detailing program activities, fire safety education programs, support materials, and efforts to secure non-Federal support. The Administrator will also submit a report to Congress. The Administrator must submit an annual report to Congress, detailing fire safety and prevention education programs conducted by eligible entities receiving funds under section 4. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 for each of fiscal years 1996 and 1997 for fire safety education, with a limit of $500,000 for administrative costs. $2,500,000 for fiscal year 1995 for data collection, with a limit of $300,000 for administrative costs. Amounts remain available until expended.
